data.title: Support octicons in quick pick
data.body:
I added Octoicons to my QuickPick list of [my extension](https://github.com/nocksock/vscode-quick-open-create) and it's looking nice. However there's a bug, when filtering for a string that's in the name of the octoicon:

![screen shot 2017-09-24 at 14 42 07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22164/30782660-a5ae0388-a136-11e7-8c0a-09cff1d44577.png)
![screen shot 2017-09-24 at 14 42 17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22164/30782661-a5ae9ac8-a136-11e7-8a08-157c1dc03442.png)

It'd be great if the interface for QuickPickItem would be something like this:
``` typescript
interface QuickPickItem {
    label: string, // unchanged
    description?: string, // unchanged
    details?: string, // unchanged
    payload?: any, // non-readable payload
    icon?: string // either name of icon (or inline svg code?)
}
```

It seems that the counter is always 1 higher than the real number

data.title: Highlight closing parens/bracket when selecting range

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
This is a feature request. I think it will be fantastically useful if when you select a range of text, the first opening parens/bracket in the range, and its corresponding closing parens/bracket, would be highlighted the same way that it's highlighted when you put the cursor next to parens.

The reason why it would be useful is that when you select a piece of code, especially if it is large, it's often hard to tell where you should end the selection, and usually that's where the closing parens/bracket is.

As as extra plus, this feature would be easily discoverable by users without needing to be told about it.

For selections with multiple ranges this can be disabled or applied to the first range - whichever is easier to implement.

data.title: Problem with sourcemaps in the latest update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0

I updated to the latest version (from the version previous to 1.16), and Code has stopped properly mapping my sources.

launch.json
```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Program",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/test/graphiql-client.js",
            "outFiles": [
                "${workspaceRoot}/build/**/*.js"
            ],
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "trace": true
        }
    ]
}
```

Truncated log from launch trace:
```
Debugging with legacy protocol because Node.js v7.7.1 was detected.

/Users/bradzacher/.nvm/versions/node/v7.7.1/bin/node --debug-brk=39467 --nolazy test/graphiql-client.js

(node:59058) DeprecationWarning: node --debug is deprecated. Please use node --inspect instead.
Debugger listening on 127.0.0.1:39467

59056: _setBreakpoint: {"type":"scriptRegExp","target":"^(.*[\\/\\\\])?\\/Users\\/bradzacher\\/Documents\\/workspace\\/core-query-api\\/build\\/lib\\/ResolverPrototype\\.js$","line":23,"column":0}

data.title: Step into awaited function
data.body: Allow to step into (f11) an awaited function in debugging session. Currently, it just steps over (probably because it's a promise).

data.title: Documentation view
data.body:
Simply, I'd like to see documentation of a method and its parameters.

Webstorm has Documentation tooltip (Ctrl+Q). With the cursor on a method and pressing ctrl+q, it shows you all needed info about the method. VS Code currently shows just the autocomplete without documentation in "TypeScript definition" format which is hard to read.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25822015/30777778-fa8b06ae-a0c2-11e7-9d90-772e9ee667e2.png)

data.title: Can we please have the ctrl mouse wheel change the code font
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-autohotkey|sle|0.2.1

I hate it when the standards are not respected, I'm sure you noticed with all my rantings.

My issue of the day is regarding the Code Editor Font Size not attached the ctrl+mouse wheel like every text/code editor out there. There's a reason the change font size is attached to the mouse wheel. people use it, especially if like me they are half blind, we use it hundreds of times an hour

You absolutely need the ability to change the font size on the fly in the code editor window because this is how blind people code:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RqGUhLW4pbs

It's not the first time I notice this omission in a code a editor, I already made that video for another Code editor whose developer also made the same bad judgement call. It's understandable if you are not visually impaired but this needs addressing.

I know you can change the UI font with ctrl - or + but that is NOT what I'm asking. for one it changes the wrong thing and for 2 it breaks the fluidity of the perusing. 

Like in Code, here, the people I made the video for also thought ctlr - or + to change the UI size was what was people needed... it's not. We need both UI AND Code size change to support people with poor eyesight. 

And I'm NOT asking to tie the mouse wheel to the UI font Size!!! It needs to be tied to the Code Box ONLY!

I dont want to zoom in my code and the whole UI explodes leaving me with no room to work with,

ctrl - or + to change the UI zoom
ctrl mouse wheel to change the codebox zoom
the code box font size is determined by the code box font settings * the codebox zoom * the UI zoom

Anyway, I hope you guys fix it.... And remember, I would not be posting suggestions or pointing out omissions if I did not care. I'm starting to like this product a whole lot tbh, but these little annoyances take their toll and end up being major hurdles over long periods of time, they need to be fixed. 



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.
2.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Add `editorFileExtension` when clause context
data.body:
This adds file extension `when` clause context.

Some languages are using same languageId for multiple different types of files (with different extensions). It may be useful to let developers define command by file extension, and not only by languageId. For example in F#, we have single languageId (fsharp) for all different types of files (.fs - normal F# files, .fsx - F# script files, .fsi - F# signature files). We would like to be able to display some commands, or menu entries only for one of the types.

1. Open any js files

console.log(() =>
(

))
```

data.title: EOL User Setting should be able to be set per language or file type.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use the following User Settings:
```
{
    "[shellscript]": {
        "files.eol": "\n", //Unknown Identifier. Use language identifiers
        "files.encoding": "utf8bom" //Unknown Identifier. Use language identifiers
    }
}
```

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

`files.encoding` and `files.eol` should be able to be set per language, much like `files.trimTrailingWhitespace` or `files.insertFinalNewline` are able to be.

On my windows machine, I edit bash scripts and the like that I use on WSL, and subsiquently `ssh` and `scp` around to actual Linux boxes. This causes some annoyances to say the least as WSL handles both but the actual systems do not.

The availability of `files.encoding` would be handy if you're editing something that can only be in ISO format like very old Python files for something like a sanity check. I've also worked with files from old game engines or the like that only take ISO as well, but still want to generally be using utf8.

data.title: The editor leaves empty space above the first line when the search panel is displayed
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16,1
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce: uknown

After I use VSCode for a while sometimes I notice that the editor leaves some empty space above the first line. It happens in all open editors and those I open next.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/296970/30771886-e26012b8-a059-11e7-8b26-acc69bc8c3b6.png)

After I restart VSCode everything is back to normal

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Delete a word based on space separator

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16

Steps to Reproduce:

1. place the cursor middle of a word. I can delete left half of the word or right half of the word but can not delete the complete word at once. like if I would like to delete a line i can do that from anywhere the cursor is on the line. but for word i would like to delete a word from anywhere the cursor is on the word.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No
